snippet: In South Korea, the government is playing a bigger role in matchmaking amid plunging birthrates and changing expectations over matrimony.
abstract: South Korea, fretful about plummeting birth rates but still tied to conservative ideas about marriage, makes matchmaking something of a national priority; in a country where arranged courtships are fading into the past, Ministry of Health and Welfare began in 2010 promoting the idea of dating parties; since then, sponsorship of the parties has shifted mainly to ministry affiliates and local governments, which can win financial rewards for activities that promote marriage and childbirth.
lead_paragraph: In South Korea, the government is playing a bigger role in matchmaking amid plunging birthrates and changing expectations over matrimony.

headline.main: Mom Wants You Married? So Does the State
headline.print_headline: Mom Wants You Married? So Does the State
